pullRequest.title: Label Resolver for Dimension Formula
pullRequest.bodyText:
Solved #1043.
Description

Add Formula. Formulas are annotations that can define customized expression on dimension or metric fields.

Add @MetricFormula

@MetricFormula would be used on metric fields to perform post-aggregation expression, it can only be used on metric fields and can only refer to metric fields.


Add @DimensionFormula.

@DimensionFormula would be used on dimension fields to perform pre-aggregation expression, it can only be used on dimension fields.
It can use path like path.to.other.field to refer to a field defined in other class. This path follows that same rule as @JoinTo.path().




Add columnType and expression to Column.

columnType is an enum which describe the source of each logical column.

FIELD if the logical column directly comes from a physical column.
REFERENCE if the logical column comes from another logical column defined in other table.
FORMULA if the logical column is using formula.


expression describes the source of the column.

FIELD column would just be the field name.
REFERENCE column would be sourceTableName.sourceColumnName
FORMULA column would be the actual formula.




Add ColumnVisitor. ColumnVisitors can convert each column into a different format or parse value from each column.

Add FormulaValidator to check reference loop.


Add SQLReference. SQLReference is the full-expanded and resolved physical reference and join paths of each SQL field. It can come from @Column for FIELD columns, @JoinTo for REFERENCE and @MetricFormula/@DimensionFormula for FORMULA columns.

Add SQLReferenceVisitor for resolving reference for each column in SQLQueryEngine
Add SQLJoinVisitor for resolving JOINs for each column in SQLQueryEngine
Add SQLReferenceTable to store all resolvers and resolved references.


Update old code to apply the changes

Remove SQLColumn, SQLDimension, SQLTimeDimension. The logic for resolving reference is moved into SQLReferenceVisitor.
Remove source column related logic from MetaDataStore.
Move reference resolving logic from Metric to SQLReferenceVisitor



Formula Rules

MetricFormula can contains references from these following two sources:


Logical metric column defined in current Table
Physical column in the physical table or subquery of current Table


DimensionFormula can contains references these following three sources:


Logical dimension column defined in current Table
Physical column in the physical table or subquery of current Table
Logical dimension column defined in other data model, use a dot-separated path as reference

That is, Metric/MetricFormula fields and Dimension/DimensionFormula fields can not refer to each other.
How Has This Been Tested?
2 new unit tests classes are added.
Totally 8 unit tests and 2 integration tests are added.
License
I confirm that this contribution is made under an Apache 2.0 license and that I have the authority necessary to make this contribution on behalf of its copyright owner.

nodes.bodyText: Adding JoinPath here exposes the implementation as part of the interface.  The interface should be simple with the minimum amount of data needed.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,146 @@
+/*
+ * Copyright 2020, Yahoo Inc.
+ * Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0
+ * See LICENSE file in project root for terms.
+ */
+package com.yahoo.elide.datastores.aggregation.metadata.models;
+
+import com.yahoo.elide.core.EntityDictionary;
+import com.yahoo.elide.core.Path;
+import com.yahoo.elide.datastores.aggregation.core.JoinPath;
+import com.yahoo.elide.datastores.aggregation.metadata.MetaDataStore;
+
+import java.util.ArrayList;
+import java.util.List;
+import java.util.Map;
+import java.util.Set;
+import java.util.stream.Collectors;
+
+/**
+ * LabelResolver is an interface for resolving column into some type of "labels" such as column reference, join
+ * path and so on. It uses Depth-First-Search approach to traverse join path vertically. The resolved results would
+ * be stored for quick access.
+ */
+public interface LabelResolver {
+    /**
+     * Resolve a label for a join path. This method need to be implemented for each column.
+     *
+     * @param fromPath path to be resolved
+     * @param toResolve paths that are pending resolving
+     * @param resolved resolved paths
+     * @param generator generator to construct labels
+     * @param metaDataStore meta data store
+     * @param <T> label value type
+     * @return resolved label
+     */
+    <T> T resolveLabel(JoinPath fromPath,
+                       Set<JoinPath> toResolve,

nodes.bodyText: Typo?  toResolve?
There should be a default constructor which does the class Scan and another constructor which allows a set of classes to be provided.
There should be a default constructor which does the class Scan and another constructor which allows a set of classes to be provided.
Do you need to escape the closing curly braces as well?
Maybe this should be moved to column?

nodes.bodyText: Is there any reason not to do this in the constructor of the MetadataStore?

I'm not sure why the QueryEngine needs to populate the metadata store.  The metadata store already knows (in its constructor) everything that needs to be resolved.  I feel like all of this logic belongs there.
I don't understand what resolveReference is trying to do in general beyond the validation.
We should add some unit tests for these functions.
nodes.diffHunk:

path extension + * @return extended path [A.B]/[B.C]/[C.D] + */ + public static

JoinPath extendJoinPath(Path path, P extension) {

nodes.bodyText: Rather than special case this, it might be simpler if physical references had resolvers that just return the column name.

I wonder if we should move all the LabelResolver stuff to SQLColumn, SQLMetric, and SQLDimension.  Its not clear to me that we want to pollute the base metadata with this.
I realize we may eventually want to expose a Metric/Dimension Formula to the UI - but that's about the only thing that seems like it properly belongs with the base metadata.
Let's make sure we have unit tests for all these functions.
This could resolve to the column name by default - so everything can have a label resolver and we don't have to special case physical columns.
This function probably belongs with the LabelStore
Use flatmap instead
Rather than returning an entity dictionary, I wonder if the LabelStore should have the methods that require the entity dictionary.

nodes.bodyText: I don't think MetaDataStore should be resolving labels.
Move to LabelStore
Move to label Store
I think it is clearer to just call the constructor directly.  I would remove this function.
I would move all this to SQLMetric
flatmap

nodes.bodyText: The code is harder to understand when we wrap constructors in one line functions.   I would remove these.
I assume we can collapse this if we move Column level logic from column to SQLColumn
I believe sourcePath and sourceColumn are going away - based on our last discussion.
I'm wondering if it would be simpler to resolve the reference field at query time - rather than this approach of doing it up front.  Let's discuss.

Using Path here is unnatural.  If you look at the code, we only use the Class (Table) and field to actually store and lookup the resolvers.   There is a lot of code that has to lookup the resolver - and that code is creating these paths again and again.   Looking up by Path I think is confusing - because the actual lookup keys are obfuscated by the Path data structure.

+package com.yahoo.elide.datastores.aggregation.metadata;

+/**
+ * LabelStore stores all label resolvers for all columns. It uses {@link JoinPath} as reference to each field.

+    /**
+     * Get a dictionary with model definitions.

+
+    /**
+     * Get the label resolver for a path
+     *
+     * @param path path to a logical field
+     * @return a label resolver
+     */
+    LabelResolver getLabelResolver(Path path);

nodes.bodyText: Let's remove all the sourcePath and sourceColumn code for now.

commit.message: move symbol table into sql query engine

nodes.bodyText: We are still using the old LabelResolver name in a few places.  This is one.
Maybe call it referenceResolver
Maybe rename as getDependentResolvers.
Is there any reason we just don't use class.newInstance here?
Maybe we should add a Precondition that the last element of path is equal to the first element of the extension.

nodes.bodyText: Do we need to check here if visited already contains the dimension?
Given this has state, should we create a new one for each column?
This looks unused.

Instead of special casing this in the query constructor, I think this might be cleaner if TimeDImension was something that can be visited in the visitor itself.  Let's discuss and see if this is possible
